Exercise 3.3.2

Prove Proposition 3.3.3. (Hint: this is very similar to Theorem 3.3.1. Theorem 3.3.1 cannot be used to prove Proposition 3.3.3, however it is possible to use Proposition 3.3.3 to prove Theorem 3.3.1.)

Proposition (3.3.3)

Let (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​) and (Y,dY)\p{Y, d_Y}(Y,dY​) be metric spaces, with YYY complete, and let EEE be a subset of XXX. Let (f(n))n=1∞\p{f^{\p{n}}}_{n=1}^\infty(f(n))n=1∞​ be a sequence of functions from EEE to YYY, and suppose that this sequence converges uniformly in EEE to some function f ⁣:E→Y\func{f}{E}{Y}f:E→Y. Let x0∈Xx_0 \in Xx0​∈X be an adherent point of EEE, and suppose that for each nnn the limit lim⁡x→x0;x∈Ef(n)(x)\lim_{x\to x_0; x \in E} f^{\p{n}}\p{x}limx→x0​;x∈E​f(n)(x) exists. Then the limit lim⁡x→x0;x∈Ef(x)\lim_{x\to x_0; x\in E} f\p{x}limx→x0​;x∈E​f(x) also exists, and is equal to the limit of the sequence (lim⁡x→x0;x∈Ef(n)(x))n=1∞\p{\lim_{x\to x_0; x\in E} f^{\p{n}}\p{x}}_{n=1}^\infty(limx→x0​;x∈E​f(n)(x))n=1∞​; in other words, we have the interchange of limits

lim⁡n→∞lim⁡x→x0;x∈Ef(n)(x)=lim⁡x→x0;x∈Elim⁡n→∞f(n)(x).\lim_{n\to\infty} \lim_{x \to x_0; x \in E} f^{\p{n}}\p{x} = \lim_{x\to x_0; x \in E} \lim_{n\to\infty} f^{\p{n}}\p{x}.n→∞lim​x→x0​;x∈Elim​f(n)(x)=x→x0​;x∈Elim​n→∞lim​f(n)(x).
Solution.

Let Ln≔lim⁡x→x0;x∈Ef(n)(x)L_n \coloneqq \lim_{x \to x_0; x \in E} f^{\p{n}}\p{x}Ln​:=limx→x0​;x∈E​f(n)(x). There are two things to prove: that (Ln)n⊆Y\p{L_n}_n \subseteq Y(Ln​)n​⊆Y converges to some L∈YL \in YL∈Y and that lim⁡x→x0;x∈Ef(x)=L\lim_{x \to x_0; x \in E} f\p{x} = Llimx→x0​;x∈E​f(x)=L.

(Ln)n\p{L_n}_n(Ln​)n​ converges:

Since YYY is complete, it suffices to show that (Ln)n\p{L_n}_n(Ln​)n​ is Cauchy. Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. Since f(n)→ff^{\p{n}} \to ff(n)→f uniformly on EEE, there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that

n,m≥N  ⟹  sup⁡x∈EdY(f(n)(x),f(m)(x))<ε3.(∗)n, m \geq N \implies \sup_{x \in E} d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, f^{\p{m}}\p{x}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}. \tag{$*$}n,m≥N⟹x∈Esup​dY​(f(n)(x),f(m)(x))<3ε​.(∗)

By definition of LnL_nLn​, for each n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, there exists δn>0\delta_n > 0δn​>0 such that

dX(x,x0)<δn  ⟹  dY(f(n)(x),Ln)<ε3.(†)d_X\p{x, x_0} < \delta_n \implies d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, L_n} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}. \tag{$\dagger$}dX​(x,x0​)<δn​⟹dY​(f(n)(x),Ln​)<3ε​.(†)

Fix n,m≥Nn, m \geq Nn,m≥N and set δnm=min⁡{δn,δm}\delta_{nm} = \min \set{\delta_n, \delta_m}δnm​=min{δn​,δm​}. Since x0∈E‾x_0 \in \cl{E}x0​∈E, there exists xnm∈E∩B(x0,δnm)x_{nm} \in E \cap B\p{x_0, \delta_{nm}}xnm​∈E∩B(x0​,δnm​). By the triangle inequality,

dY(Ln,Lm)≤dY(Ln,f(n)(xnm))+dY(f(n)(xnm),f(m)(xnm))+dY(f(m)(xnm),Lm).\begin{aligned} d_Y\p{L_n, L_m} &\leq d_Y\p{L_n, f^{\p{n}}\p{x_{nm}}} \\ &\hspace{0.5in} + d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x_{nm}}, f^{\p{m}}\p{x_{nm}}} \\ &\hspace{0.5in} + d_Y\p{f^{\p{m}}\p{x_{nm}}, L_m}. \end{aligned}dY​(Ln​,Lm​)​≤dY​(Ln​,f(n)(xnm​))+dY​(f(n)(xnm​),f(m)(xnm​))+dY​(f(m)(xnm​),Lm​).​

By construction, we have dX(xnm,x0)<δnd_X\p{x_{nm}, x_0} < \delta_ndX​(xnm​,x0​)<δn​ and dX(xnm,x0)<δmd_X\p{x_{nm}, x_0} < \delta_mdX​(xnm​,x0​)<δm​, we can apply (†\dagger†) to the first and third terms. Lastly, because xnm∈Ex_{nm} \in Exnm​∈E and n,m≥Nn, m \geq Nn,m≥N, we can apply (∗*∗) to the second term. Putting everything together, we have

dY(Ln,Lm)<ε3+ε3+ε3=εd_Y\p{L_n, L_m} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3} + \frac{\varepsilon}{3} + \frac{\varepsilon}{3} = \varepsilondY​(Ln​,Lm​)<3ε​+3ε​+3ε​=ε

for all n,m≥Nn, m \geq Nn,m≥N. Thus, (Ln)n\p{L_n}_n(Ln​)n​ is Cauchy.

lim⁡x→x0;x∈Ef(x)=L\lim_{x\to x_0; x \in E} f\p{x} = Llimx→x0​;x∈E​f(x)=L:

Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. By uniform convergence, there exists N1∈NN_1 \in \NN1​∈N such that

n≥N1  ⟹  sup⁡x∈EdY(f(x),f(n)(x))<ε3.(∗)n \geq N_1 \implies \sup_{x \in E} d_Y\p{f\p{x}, f^{\p{n}}\p{x}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}. \tag{$*$}n≥N1​⟹x∈Esup​dY​(f(x),f(n)(x))<3ε​.(∗)

As above, for any n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, there exists δn>0\delta_n > 0δn​>0 such that

dX(x,x0)<δn  ⟹  dY(f(n)(x),Ln)<ε3.(†)d_X\p{x, x_0} < \delta_n \implies d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, L_n} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}. \tag{$\dagger$}dX​(x,x0​)<δn​⟹dY​(f(n)(x),Ln​)<3ε​.(†)

Lastly, because Ln→LL_n \to LLn​→L, there exists N2∈NN_2 \in \NN2​∈N such that

n≥N2  ⟹  sup⁡x∈EdY(Ln,L)<ε3.(‡)n \geq N_2 \implies \sup_{x \in E} d_Y\p{L_n, L} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}. \tag{$\ddagger$}n≥N2​⟹x∈Esup​dY​(Ln​,L)<3ε​.(‡)

Let n0=max⁡{N1,N2}n_0 = \max\set{N_1, N_2}n0​=max{N1​,N2​} and let x∈Ex \in Ex∈E be such that dX(x,x0)<δn0d_X\p{x, x_0} < \delta_{n_0}dX​(x,x0​)<δn0​​. By the triangle inequality,

dY(f(x),L)≤dY(f(x),f(n0)(x))+dY(f(n0)(x),Ln0)+dY(Ln0,L).\begin{aligned} d_Y\p{f\p{x}, L} &\leq d_Y\p{f\p{x}, f^{\p{n_0}}\p{x}} \\ &\hspace{0.5in} + d_Y\p{f^{\p{n_0}}\p{x}, L_{n_0}} \\ &\hspace{0.5in} + d_Y\p{L_{n_0}, L}. \end{aligned}dY​(f(x),L)​≤dY​(f(x),f(n0​)(x))+dY​(f(n0​)(x),Ln0​​)+dY​(Ln0​​,L).​

Since n0≥N1n_0 \geq N_1n0​≥N1​, the first term is less than ε3\frac{\varepsilon}{3}3ε​ by (∗*∗). Similarly, because n0≥N2n_0 \geq N_2n0​≥N2​ also, we may apply (‡\ddagger‡) to see that the third term is also less than ε3\frac{\varepsilon}{3}3ε​. Finally, because dX(x,x0)<δn0d_X\p{x, x_0} < \delta_{n_0}dX​(x,x0​)<δn0​​, (†\dagger†) implies that the second term is also bounded by ε3\frac{\varepsilon}{3}3ε​. Putting everything together,

dY(f(x),Ln)<ε3+ε3+ε3=ε.d_Y\p{f\p{x}, L_n} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3} + \frac{\varepsilon}{3} + \frac{\varepsilon}{3} = \varepsilon.dY​(f(x),Ln​)<3ε​+3ε​+3ε​=ε.

This completes the proof.

Exercise 3.3.4

Prove Proposition 3.3.4. (Hint: again, this is similar to Theorem 3.3.1 and Proposition 3.3.3, although the statements are slightly different, and one cannot deduce this directly from the other two results.)

Proposition (3.3.4)

Let (f(n))n=1∞\p{f^{\p{n}}}_{n=1}^\infty(f(n))n=1∞​ be a sequence of continuous functions from one metric space (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​) to another (Y,dY)\p{Y, d_Y}(Y,dY​), and suppose that this sequence converges uniformly to another function f ⁣:X→Y\func{f}{X}{Y}f:X→Y. Let x(n)x^{\p{n}}x(n) be a sequence of points in XXX which converge to some limit xxx. Then f(n)(x(n))f^{\p{n}}\p{x^{\p{n}}}f(n)(x(n)) converges (in YYY) to f(x)f\p{x}f(x).
Solution.

Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. Since f(n)→ff^{\p{n}} \to ff(n)→f uniformly, there exists N1∈NN_1 \in \NN1​∈N such that

n≥N1  ⟹  sup⁡z∈XdY(f(z),f(n)(z))<ε2.(∗)n \geq N_1 \implies \sup_{z \in X} d_Y\p{f\p{z}, f^{\p{n}}\p{z}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{2}. \tag{$*$}n≥N1​⟹z∈Xsup​dY​(f(z),f(n)(z))<2ε​.(∗)

Because continuity is preserved under uniform limits, we immediately have that fff is continuous. Thus, because x(n)→xx^{\p{n}} \to xx(n)→x, we know f(x(n))→f(x)f\p{x^{\p{n}}} \to f\p{x}f(x(n))→f(x) as well, so there exists N2∈NN_2 \in \NN2​∈N such that

n≥N2  ⟹  dY(f(x(n)),f(x))<ε2.(†)n \geq N_2 \implies d_Y\p{f\p{x^{\p{n}}}, f\p{x}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{2}. \tag{$\dagger$}n≥N2​⟹dY​(f(x(n)),f(x))<2ε​.(†)

Let n≥max⁡{N1,N2}n \geq \max\set{N_1, N_2}n≥max{N1​,N2​}. Then by the triangle inequality,

dY(f(n)(x(n)))≤dY(f(n)(x(n)),f(x(n)))+dY(f(x(n)),f(x)).\begin{aligned} d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x^{\p{n}}}} &\leq d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x^{\p{n}}}, f\p{x^{\p{n}}}} \\ &\hspace{0.5in}+ d_Y\p{f\p{x^{\p{n}}}, f\p{x}}. \end{aligned}dY​(f(n)(x(n)))​≤dY​(f(n)(x(n)),f(x(n)))+dY​(f(x(n)),f(x)).​

As before, since n≥N1n \geq N_1n≥N1​, (∗*∗) may be applied to the first term and because n≥N2n \geq N_2n≥N2​ also, (†\dagger†) may be applied to the second term. Thus,

dY(f(n)(x(n)))<ε2+ε2=ε.d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x^{\p{n}}}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{2} + \frac{\varepsilon}{2} = \varepsilon.dY​(f(n)(x(n)))<2ε​+2ε​=ε.
